subject: Kokusai Tosogu Kai Book and a few other books of interest

I want to take a moment to wish all of you a healthy and
treasure-filled 20=
06, and bring to your attention a new publication of
interest to Kodogu col=
lectors, and a few other books not quite so new.

Of the 600 copies of this=
 book, 200 were reserved for Japan and sold
out. Most of the remainder were=
 bought by the non-Japanese membership,
and some of you reading this might =
have received a copy as a gift over
the holidays. I have been given a small=
 number to sell, and am
delighted to offer:

NAKAMURA, NICK, EDITOR. Kokusa=
i Tosogu Kai, 2005 International
Convention & Exhibition. Tokyo: Kokusai To=
sogu Kai, 2005. First
edition. 108 p. The catalog of the first Exhibition o=
f Kokusai Tosogu
Kai, an international group dedicated to the study and app=
reciation of
 tosogu, or Japanese sword fittings. Held in Louisville, Kentu=
cky, at
the Frazier Historical Arms Museum, the exhibition featured items f=
rom
Canadian and U.S., and Japanese collections. The Japanese items, most
n=
ever having been exhibited outside of Japan, were professionally
photograph=
ed for the catalog, and reproduced to the highest standards.
The catalog al=
so features a 14 page article by Robert Haynes, "My
First Sixty Years as a =
Student of Kodogu," complemented by photos from
his personal archives docum=
enting his years of study. Also included is
an insightful colloquy between =
Ms. Taeko Watanabe, president of the
Sano Museum in Mishima, and Terukata K=
awabata,  NBTHK Director and
Director of Kokusai Budo Renme (International =
Martial Arts Federation)
on "Sukashi Tsuba, Their Use and Aesthetic Beauty.=
" A beautifully
produced book and a rare treat for students of Japanese swo=
rd
fittings. Limited to 600 copies. Hard Cover with Slipcase.
New.	$150.00
=

Not to ignore sword collectors, I have on hand a recent publication
that w=
as mentioned on one of the lists not long ago:

KAWACHI, KUNIHIRA AND MANAB=
E, MASAO. The Art of the Japanese Sword As
Taught by the Experts. Tokyo: Ri=
bun, 2004. First English language
edition. ISBN: 4898062261. 156 p. This is=
 a great little book, part
introduction for beginners, bits of history, a f=
abulous section of
pictures of every phase of the making of Nihonto. All of=
 this from the
perspective of a working mukansa smith. The introductory sec=
tions will
be most useful to new collectors, but many things are pointed ou=
t that
are missing from the other classic introductory texts. Handy directo=
ry
to museums world-wide where Japanese swords can be seen.  Glossy
Pictori=
al Cover. New.  $65.00

And another excellent sword reference from the othe=
r side of the globe:

SIONG, HAN BING. Japanese Swords in Dutch Collections=
 A Selection from
500 Descriptions in the Series Japanse Zwaarden in Nederl=
and Bezit.
Rijswijk, Netherlands: The Netherlands Token Society, 2003. Firs=
t
edition. 244 p. Translated from the Dutch by J. M. Bonsel and M.
Laros. T=
his selection of  85 blades of the 500 cataloged by Han Bing
Song since 197=
9 was published to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the
Netherlands Token =
Society. The cataloging project included swords in
museums as well as priva=
te collections. Of those presented in this
book, a range of swords from Kot=
o through Gendaito are shown with
oshigata and Mr. Han's scholarly and insi=
ghtful comments.  Seventeen
of the blades are also presented in photographs=
, and there are 14
pages of full color photographs of the best of the koshi=
rae. An
outstanding publication of the highest quality and most valuable
co=
ntent. Pictorial Hardcover. New. 	$125.00

Back to fittings, I have been th=
oroughly enjoying the next recently
published book. Mr. Ito was a student o=
f Sasano, and I am told that
this volume is to be followed by another on Hi=
rata Hikozo. I'm keeping
my fingers crossed!

ITO, MITSURO. Works of Kanshi=
ro Nishigaki. Tokyo: 2005. First edition.
A lavishly produced survey of the=
 works of the four generations of
Kanshiro Nishigaki, one of the four major=
 Higo fittings makers. All
color photos, over 250 items, text in Japanese b=
ut photo captions also
in English. Hard Cover with Slipcase. New. $275.00

=
Finally, I have to mention a book that every student of the Arts of
Japan o=
ught to have. This was very hard to find and quite expensive
for many years=
 until the bulk of the 2000 copies, which had been
stored since the late '7=
0s, were located a little over a year ago.
Anyone who has a copy of "Legend=
 in Japanese Art" should have this,
and if you don't have a copy of Joly's =
book, I can help you with that
as well.

TOMPKINS, JOHN BARR, AND DOROTHY C=
AMPBELL TOMPKINS . People, Places
and Things in Henri Joly's Legend in Japa=
nese Art An Analytical Index.
Alexandria VA: Kirin Books & Art, 1978. First=
 and only edition. 217 p.
 In response to a letter written to the Internati=
onal Netsuke
Collectors Society Journal, and based on their own frustration=
 in
using "Legend," the authors produced an analytical subject index to
Hen=
ri Joly's essential reference work "Legend in Japanese Art."  A
limited edi=
tion of 2000 copies.  Hard Cover with Dust Jacket. New.  
$35.00

Of course=
 I have many other books listed on my website, and continue
to add inventor=
y from the shelves and many boxes of uncataloged books
that drive my wife c=
razy! If there is a book you have been searching
for that you don't see, pl=
ease ask as it's likely I have it.

I want to thank all of you that have su=
pported my efforts over the
past year, and I continue to look forward to th=
e satisfaction I get
from finding great homes for great books. I'm preparin=
g for the Tampa
show, and hope to spend time there with friends both old an=
d new.

Craig
